106625: Sacred Mesa.author: humor_love
106625: Sacred Mesa.text_parsed:
Easily among the best token-production cards in the game. Only Mycoloth gives this card a run for its 'money', as far as I can see it at the moment. Dragon Broodmother falls not far behind them - the dragon's just limited to one token per upkeep, like Verdant Force and Verdant Embrace.

The forced sacrifice just keeps this card balanced.

... I guess I should also mention Mirror-Sigil Sergeant and Luminarch Ascension; but they both have requirements beyond casting cost and beyond mechanics internal to the card itself. Even Mycoloth requires other edible creatures under your control before entering play (and that you actually sacrifice them to Mycoloth), before it produces its own tokens. Also, Luminarch's Ascension requires quite a bit of work before it can produce tokens for you: it normally needs to be in play for at least 4 of your opponents' turns.
106625: Sacred Mesa.text_posted:

The forced sacrifice just keeps this card balanced.

106631: Dandân.author: Aquillion
106631: Dandân.text_parsed:
This card isn't quite as bad as it seems at first. Compare to Wall of Torches -- if you're already running Spreading Seas or something similar, this card can act as cheap defense that will likely trade off with something costing more, and if you get an island on your opponent's side of the board, it can also attack.

It's not great, but even a 4/1 defender for two mana wasn't so bad back in the day.

106631: Dandân.author: Phelplan
106631: Dandân.text_parsed:
@DaaNz "fish don't swim vertically"

You haven't seen very many fish, have you?
Blue gills and many other sunfish do a very good job of swimming vertically when they are eating stuff floating on the surface of the water.
Great white sharks and many other fish will swim vertically when they rush the surface in order to pounce on their prey.
I'm sure there are numerous other examples. It is pretty common really.

106638: Sengir Autocrat.author: longwinded
106638: Sengir Autocrat.text_parsed:
The great update has been schizophrenic towards tokens.

Best guess: there are some old tokens where some tribal synergy was by design (goblin, thrull, and saproling tokens), some where it is reasonable to expect an update (Boris Devilboon's "minor demon" should be a demon), and some where they're type is irrelevant, because they were never meant to be anything more than a cheap, generic token. These are those generic tokens.

106638: Sengir Autocrat.author: Antsache
106638: Sengir Autocrat.text_parsed:
The "Serf" type is kind of awkward, but if they were to update it I'm not sure "Minion" would be the best choice. Minion tokens are 1/1 or X/X; there's no precedent there for 0/1. Minion as a non-token type is used for some powerful individuals, such as Braids and Chainer, and even Rag Man is clearly more capable than a mere 0/1 townsperson. There's the problem, I'm guessing, and the real reason they still haven't updated the type: 0/1 isn't used for anything that really makes sense (unless they want to use the serfs' livestock in the form of Goat tokens :P), and Minion doesn't seem all that close a fit flavor-wise. Likewise, Human tokens (which are probably closer in flavor) are 1/1.

If they made this make 0/1 Minion tokens, they'd be adding a third p/t standard for an already-inconsistent token. I'd rather have seen them just embrace the "serf" type and run out a set that where ability-less 0/1's could be utilized (via sac, etc...) by several cards. Unfortunately, Innistrad has now come and gone, and those Vampire-centered sets seem like they'd have fit this idea perfectly. They likely felt it would ring too similar to the Eldrazi spawn mechanic. Still, I like the idea that they might come back to this at some point. In the meantime, I'll have to just accept that your average farmer seems capable of fighting well-trained soldiers to a standstill :/

106639: Celestial Dawn.author: scumbling1
106639: Celestial Dawn.text_parsed: I've never been a fan of cards such as Celestial Dawn and Prismatic Omen, for much the same reason I'm not a fan of Mana Cylix. All the aforementioned cards fix your mana, but they still require a whole card out of your deck to do only that. They don't actually give you access to more mana, which playing something like a Cultivate or a Signet would (and these cards could simultaneously help gain access to additional colors of mana while doing so). You can just get around color screw by simply using a combination of a solid mana base along with running accelerants. Outside of decks with Sen Triplets, if you need this level of color-fixing you probably should rethink the cards in you're using.

106639: Celestial Dawn.author: RexManningDay
106639: Celestial Dawn.text_parsed: To prevent confusion, it's probably worth noting that (as far as I know) the Donate shenanigans with this card only work in EDH. In other formats, giving this away turns the other player's lands into Plains, which now produce white mana, which can be used as any color. So the other player isn't really hurt by it, unless they're relying heavily on non-land mana.

106639: Celestial Dawn.author: endersblade
106639: Celestial Dawn.text_parsed:
Contrary to what people seem to think, this card does jack squat against your opponent in EDH. You give this to him, and all his stuff becomes white, and all his lands tap for white. If anything, you just helped someone running multiple colors make their deck extremely mana efficient.

You aren't allowed to add mana to your mana pool as any color other than what color(s) your general are. Ok, cool, guess what, he just became white. On top of that, as this card clearly states, you can use the mana produced while this enchant is in play as ANY COLOR.

Actually, I can't see a use in donating this period, be it EDH or otherwise. It's good for mana fixing, as it makes all of your lands essentially tap for . It does ruin any non-basics that have useful abilities, like Mikokoro, Center of the Sea, Gaea's Cradle, etc, which is a definite pain. But if you're running this card in a deck, you'd be extremely stupid to be running cards like that in the first place.

You aren't allowed to add mana to your mana pool as any color other than what color(s) your general are.  Ok, cool, guess what, he just became white.  On top of that, as this card clearly states, you can use the mana produced while this enchant is in play as ANY COLOR.

106639: Celestial Dawn.author: AFolcon
106639: Celestial Dawn.text_parsed:
@endersblade Actually, it does work in EDH. The rules state, "A deck may not generate mana outside its colours. If an effect would generate mana of an illegal colour, it generates colourless mana instead." Also, "A card's colour identity is established before the game begins, and cannot be changed by game effects."

So if you give this to someone and their general isn't white, their general becomes white and their lands become Plains. But since the deck's colour identity can't be changed, all those Plains will produce colourless mana, leaving them unable to cast coloured spells.

You're right about not wanting to donate it in any non-EDH game, though.

106639: Celestial Dawn.author: casual_melvin
106639: Celestial Dawn.text_parsed:
@ryabede

Celestial dawn does not change color words in the rules text of a card. (it will change the color of things like transguild courier, which no longer has any rules text)

Therefore Gray Merchant of Asphodel still has devotion to black,


Prior to 2004 it would have changed the mana symbols of your permanents to white, thus making devotion to black pointless.

It no longer changes mana symbols, just color, land types and the ways mana can be used to pay costs


Therefore Gray Merchant's works just as well with this as without it.

106642: Lord of Atlantis.author: T-101
106642: Lord of Atlantis.text_parsed:
This card is a huge mystery to me. I think some of this was explained in a "Card of the Day" on magicthegathering.com, but I'll repost and elaborate.

For one, when he first saw print, he merely turned Merfolk of the Pearl Trident into a 2/2. No other Merfolk existed, and he didn't pump other copies of himself.

Secondly, he is the only 2-drop true lord (one that gives +1/+1 to his friends), which is extremely aggressively costed... yet he is mono-blue, the least likely color to get aggressively costed creatures.

Third, he himself does not get Islandwalk. WTF? He is the freaking master of the sunken city, and yet he can only show his friends, or other copies of himself how to become unblockable.

Still, all of these weird attributes can't stop this guy from being one of the scariest creatures to hit the Legacy battlefield.

"Summon Lord of Atlantis" with "All merfolk get...." 1993 version of me wouldn'tve understood that two of these guys out will get +1/+1 and islandwalk.

Later, we have him as summon lord, and saying "Other merfolk" which indirectly indicated he's a merfolk.

LAST TRY they got it right? Type - merfolk lord. "Other merfolk." Done.

Better late than never :)

106642: Lord of Atlantis.author: upgraded
106642: Lord of Atlantis.text_parsed:
@T-101

The original cycle of lords correspond to 3 vanilla creatures in alpha. The idea was that the game was so complicated already that you needed some simple cards, but it was pretty easy for simple cards to be boring. So, Richard Garfield attached hidden complexity to simple cards by giving them each a lord.

Why does the blue one cost 2 mana? Blue's just like that, you kind of have to get used to that if you want to play magic. XD

106644: Soul Collector.author: Mistralis
106644: Soul Collector.text_parsed:
@Uberslapper

You are right, but for a different reason. When tokens leave the battlefield, for any reason, in any way (shuffled into library, bounced into hand, exiled, or just plain killed), they are exiled permanently and do not return. For example, if you Oblivion Ring a token and kill the O-Ring, the token won't come back.

However, if a token dies, it doesn't instantly get exiled; it dies then gets exiled. So death triggers will still work.

106645: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed: It's almost a comedy sketch, the number of ways in which Akroma hardly ever actually wins a game... be it Swords to Plowshares, Counterspell, Icy Manipulator, Wing Snare, Hurricane or just a really big blocker, she seems to have this amazing talent for never actually working against W, U, G or artifacts, no matter what deck she's in or who's piloting her. I'd almost feel sorry for her, if she wasn't such an irritating cow in the Otaria series.

106645: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: Man-in-the-Hat
106645: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed:
When I got this card, I'd almost assume it were a gamewinner... but after playing with her in my mono-white deck for a few months, I've only used her once to pull off victory. Useually she becomes nothing more then a powerful blocker to prevent my opponent from attacking me with flying creatures.

Victory normally comes from either Armored Ascension, or a well placed attack with my balloonist... granting flying to a powerful creature without.

I've even considered taking her out of my deck to replace with a soldier card, since I play a mostly soldier deck.

106645: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.author: sarroth
106645: Akroma, Angel of Wrath.text_parsed: Akroma is indeed easy to take out. My friend and I were playing each other with our W decks just for the hell of it, and he tossed out Akroma and went for my throat. I defended with Serra Angel and turned his smirk and shrug into a barely concealed rage when I used Righteousness to turn my angel into an 11/11. Regardless, Akroma's 6/6 with all of those abilities are quite nice. Of course she's going to be targeted, especially by blue decks which she has no defense against. If she is targeted, fine, the blue opponent I'm playing against just used a counter on my 6/6 Akroma and now I get to use Armored Ascension or equip Whispersilk Cloaks on whatever card I like. Anyway, my point is that just because a card is a target does not mean it does not have a place in a deck. As far as I am concerned, Akroma fills my deck as a red herring so my opponents get scared about the wrong thing. 4.5/5 due to the weakness against blue, but this card will always be one of my favorites.

106651: Whispers of the Muse.author: DarthParallax
106651: Whispers of the Muse.text_parsed:
Funny thing about Blue.

This is the worst 'draw spell' I've ever seen. It's not even the best cantrip of all time.

And yet Randy Beuhler saw fit to use 4 in Draw-Go, a deck which is now immortalized in Gold Border as World Championship worthy.

So, what I take from this is, Blue is an ***, and
UU: Instant
Flip a coin. If someone other than you or your opponent notices the flip, and calls it correctly, draw a card.

Is in fact a broken a card.

No, seriously. Krark's Thumb. There is no such thing as a bad instant speed draw spell. There might not even be such a thing as a draw spell that's not broken.

Play Blue/x, Red/x, or go home. there's no room for non-red, non-blue Magic decks anymore. Even if you're pulling something like G/B/u Rock, its probably that u that pushes your deck into Stupid Land more than the G or B.

106651: Whispers of the Muse.author: Nagoragama
106651: Whispers of the Muse.text_parsed: This is an incredible draw engine because it can be used over and over. In a counterspell heavy blue deck, you keep your mana open on their turn, and if they don't play anything you need to counter, then you cast this with buyback at the end of their turn. Every turn you don't need to counter something or have sufficient mana, you're drawing an extra card.

106662: Wall of Roots.text_parsed:
@ Rhymes


You can also use Wall of Roots twice.

Once during your turn, to cast Birds of Paradise and one during the enemy turn, to cast something like Mana Leak.


This card is one of the best ramp walls for a U/G Control, since it essentially taps for an extra mana while I am using spells with Convoke.

4/5, for being awesome in a rogue Modern Deck.

107275: Safe Haven.author: Ritius
107275: Safe Haven.text_parsed:
If you invest a lot in your creatures, it's nice to have a way to snatch them out of the way of your opponent's removal. Of course you're still at risk of land removal, bounce, whatever, but so long as you don't substitute it for mana producing lands, it can function decently enough.
Just wish you could sac it at any time, even for a cost. That would make it clutch.

107275: Safe Haven.author: GrimjawxRULES
107275: Safe Haven.text_parsed:
Generally a pretty powerful card, but very weak against land destruction. Also a really good card against Wrath of God and Day of Judgement - hide your biggest threat in response to the board sweeper, and return it on your next turn to beat down your opponent with no resistance whatsoever... Hey, that gives me an idea! :

Safe Haven, Sun Titan, Day of Judgement/Wrath of God!

- Use Safe Haven to exile your Sun Titan and sweep the board. Crack Safe Haven on your next turn and start returning your army and beating your opponents down faster than they can possibly recover.
I could imagine running this combo in a Knight deck with Knight Exemplar, as its manacost is just low enough to allow you to resurrect it with Sun Titan. White Knight and Moorish Cavalry could also fit in, and the same goes for Honor of the Pure.

~Happy brewing folks :D

107278: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.author: i_was_like_you
107278: Evil Eye of Orms-by-Gore.text_parsed:
I had an old Evil Eye / Juggernaut deck. Every creature in the deck either could not be blocked by walls or could only be blocked by walls. It limited people's blocking options.

I'm glad that, so far, WOTC hasn't changed the Rules as Written to reflect the change from Walls to creatures with Defender. All walls have defender, but not all creatures with defender are walls.

It still would make more sense to me if creatures like Juggernaut destroyed any wall that blocked them as it was made to smash down walls.

Definitely running an Evil Eye / Changeling deck, along with 4 Skeletal Changeling.

Attack - Evil eye is nigh-unblockable, and Skeletal Changeling can too (counts as an eye).
Defense - Legerdermain their best creature in exchange for an Evil Eye. Skeletal can block, 'cause it counts as a wall too.

That and Evil Eye of Urborg and Skeletal both work great with Nemesis Mask. Blocking will never be the same again!

107280: Goblin Snowman.author: Paolino
107280: Goblin Snowman.text_parsed:
Goblin Snowman costs four mana, Baneslayer Angel costs five.
Gobiln Snowman is a Goblin, and so it has a tribal component, Tarmogoyf has not.
Goblin Snowman prevents all combat damage, Vampire Nighthawk doesn't.
Goblin Snowman can deal direct damage, Jace can't.
Goblin Snowman is 1/1, Ali From Cairo is 0/1 for the same CMC.

So... Every part of Goblin Snowman is STRICTLY BETTER than that of one of the most powerful cards in Magic. And I haven't talked about the artwork...

107283: Icatian Javelineers.author: Mode
107283: Icatian Javelineers.text_parsed:
Could anybody tell me why exactly Wizards decided to use the most awful artwork from those available for the timeshifted reprint?!

No offense against the artist, but i just don't like that one for having this strange black shadow and that apogryphal background.

There were three artworks for this card in total:
This one from Scott Kirschner, a satisfactory one from Melissa Benson (notice her typical monogram on the wall), and a really handsome one from Edward Beard, Jr.

That's my opinion, but i'm sure i'm not the only one thinking that way.

107283: Icatian Javelineers.author: DoctorKenneth
107283: Icatian Javelineers.text_parsed:
I agree that this is the worst art of the three by far, Mode, but I'd swap your placement of the other two. Handsome? That man doesn't have muscles, he has grapefruits under his forearms and flesh-coloured plate mail. He's vaguely herculean and dashing, I'll admit, but that gives him no excuse to have t-rex arms and a box for a head.

Oddly enough, despite the pluralization, this is the only art with multiple creatures in it, as much as they are, in fact, what happens when a Planeswalker attempts to summon beings from Graffiti Kingdom.

Though at least Phil Foglio didn't go anywhere near this. That we can all agree on, I'm sure.

i totally disagree with all of you. this version of the card is far superior to the others in many ways. Balance, texture, composition, colour and tone are all design elements present within the Scott Kirschner. its a much more interesting piece than the other 2 versions.

the minimalistic art style that Magic had in the earlier sets is missing from the newer cards. they made the correct decision chosing this version over the others.

107291: Flying Men.author: yyukichigai
107291: Flying Men.text_parsed:
What's funny about this card is that right after it came out Wizards backpedaled from the concept. Yes, Blue gets most of the mana-efficient flying creatures, but White and Green ere supposed to be the colors of low-cost "weenie" creatures. White got Suntail Hawk, Green got Scryb Sprites, and this was before Color Pie went into effect. Afterward Blue had even less in the way of cheap flyers for a while.

All this fear over a 1/1. Then again, this was back in the day of Blue already having an answer to everything (Counterspell et al), but I still find it silly. In all the games I've ever seen Flying Men come out, they've never turned the tide. Bought a turn, maybe, but never turned the tide.

107291: Flying Men.author: Aquillion
107291: Flying Men.text_parsed:
Jace's Phantasm is better. Even ignoring its ability and thinking in terms of creature type -- yes, human has more support, but not, generally, in blue.

A Lord of the Unreal works much better with a small weenie evasion strategy than anything humans have available, since it simultaneously makes your tiny evading illusions more threatening, and makes them immune to removal, leaving your opponent with no way to handle them. Krovikan Mist and Narcomoeba fit in, too.

What are you going to do with this, by comparison? None of the human support is really very relevant for a small blue evasion card.

107294: Ghost Ship.author: Zaneshift
107294: Ghost Ship.text_parsed: I suppose someone has to write some long, serious comment. Not me, mind you. Still, it's one more than a wall of air, switch a point of toughness into power, and give it regenerate, all while getting rid of defender. Not the best creature, but a blue regenerating creature with flying is certainly valuable, since you don't have to worry about removal spells when running a blue deck. Not worth it in anything other than a mono-blue deck, and even then it depends. Still, regenerate in a blue deck is certainly a curve-ball move, and what's more blue than keeping your foes off balance?

107299: Browbeat.author: majinara
107299: Browbeat.text_parsed:
The card got its ups and downs.
It's somehow a "win more" card. If your opponent is very low on life, and has no choice but letting you draw cards, then you'll most likely win no matter what you do.
If your opponent is though having the upper hand, it's a "lose more" card. He'll just take 5 damage and you're most likely back to topdeck mode.

In aggressive 1vs1 decks it's ok. In any format though where you start with more than 20 life (edh/commander, 2hg or whatnot) it sucks.

107299: Browbeat.author: blurrymadness
107299: Browbeat.text_parsed:
You can also consider Runeflare Trap and target the opponent. They'll *really* likely take the three cards, then eat 7-8 damage.

You only want to do this if you played your burn right to begin with and if their hand size is large enough that it results in you killing them; but it IS an option.

Same goes for Spiteful Visions and other pain-draws. If they're on their last 9 life, they die either way if you have a couple of pain draws out. (take 4 on the draw, take either 5 or 6 right now, => dead.)

Considering that's a T4-T5 play to end the game, that can also work. Yeah they pick what's best for them, but if the difference is "You take 6 damage" vs. "You take 5 damage", it's doable to force the endgame when you draw this late.

108787: Teferi's Moat.author: Cyberium
108787: Teferi's Moat.text_parsed:
People might've missed one key different between Teferi's Moat and the original Moat. Specifically, Moat stops every creature without flying from attacking anyone, but Teferi's Moat only affects opponent's creatures. This allow you to attack with your own land creatures, which is an advantage over the original Moat.

Of course, the old Moat is still more powerful, but Teferi's version is not without its merit.

108789: Gaea's Blessing.author: Lateralis0ne
108789: Gaea's Blessing.text_parsed: I've seen an awesome deck that utilizes this, Serra Avatar (as the only creature), Oath of Druids, and the Conditional Recurring Dragon Auras from Scourge. Mill through your deck with Oath of Druids for the Avatar, the Auras come out of your graveyard attached to the Avatar, and the Blessing puts everything back in, so you don't kill yourself on the forced drawing deal. Very smooth...especially with lots of lifegain in the beginning of the deck's run.

108789: Gaea's Blessing.author: Olliemancer
108789: Gaea's Blessing.text_parsed: This card two basic purposes;  it allows you to avoid being milled and allows you to get some cards back from your graveyard.  Plus, it replaces itself.  However, quite a few times two of those with Futuresight and Time Walk allowed me to win games without my basic combos and was a lifesaver...  in some occasions, you may even want to screw a graveyard themed deck by returning key cards into the player's library and still draw a card or you can get back a few cards to your partner if you play in team...  all this for two!  Not exactly a broken card, but a pretty good jack of all trades...  Not to mention combos with Oath of Druids to abuse the second ability...

108789: Gaea's Blessing.author: Fictionarious
108789: Gaea's Blessing.text_parsed:
Splash green for just two in your any color/strategy deck, what does that deck now have?
Immunity to any mill but the Raven Guild Master variety. (Traumatize no longer fazes you, and you start rooting against seeing lands when you get hit with a Mind Funeral)
The capacity to win wars of attrition where you and and the opponent can't touch one another and they've got nothing like this.
An occasional but always welcome ability to shuffle destroyed permanents and countered spells back into your deck.
If you're lucky, the early-game disruption to get big creatures out of necromancer's hands before they can cast exhume, necromancy, or unearth and swing with their new 7/7 Thraximundar that they buried alive last turn.
Card draw in a pinch.
And a classically named and illustrated card.
Six stars out of five from me.

108789: Gaea's Blessing.author: DarthParallax
108789: Gaea's Blessing.text_parsed:
Sparkle Tiger: I'd say this does much less damage to mill decks than all the creatures that this or nearly this ability. This does not forward you winning the game (though it's a great survival card.)

A deck of 30 Forests and 30 Gaea's Blessings will do much worse than a deck of 5x each Kozileks/Emrakuls/Ulamogs/Darksteel;Blightsteel Colossi/Progenitus and 30 Lotus Petals.

Is anyone else surprised (but pleasantly so) that neither Avacyn nor Griselbrand have that ability? Seemed like it was about to become 'the thing we put on all unkillable Mythic Monsters'. It nearly makes flavor sense on the Eldrazi, happened to debut on Colossus 1 so it had to be on Colossus 2....but Progenitus really doesn't need it. :/

But anyway, I'd that. ;)

I understand this card is good, but I dislike it for a different reason than 'hates mill'. I want Wizards in the future to make Anti Milling cards look more like Abundance- i.e. try not to make them so graveyard-interactive....you know....good with....well, self-milling? -.-

108789: Gaea's Blessing.author: blurrymadness
108789: Gaea's Blessing.text_parsed:
If you're running green, a 1-of in this in legacy isn't all that bad. You can shuffle a bunch of stuff from the graveyards into the library to shrink goyfs back to "tiny", you can save Game-1 against painter decks, you can have main-decked gravehate, and worst case scenario? It draws you a card.

It's useful in nearly any matchup you're bound to face and worth a *lot* more in game 1 than in game 2. Funny enough, it also forces a shuffle; which is nice if someone Brainstorm's to hide a card from your discard.) Just shuffle it away and this becomes virtual card advantage (as their combo was lost anyway and you caused discard AND you drew a card!)

Always good as a 1-of IMO.

108791: Undertaker.author: BegleOne
108791: Undertaker.text_parsed: I'd much recommend Tortured Existence.

108791: Undertaker.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
108791: Undertaker.text_parsed:
My favourite utility creature (in second and third places I'd place Llanowar Elves and Merfolk Looter, respectively). It's doesn't hurt to drop this early game, and later it gives you such a wide range of options from whatever cards you have in hand (specially if you have madness or some kind of graveyard shenanigans, which you probably do since you're playing black) that it becomes priceless. It's much like a Fauna Shaman.
If your opponent realizes this can probably be a bigger threat than any other creature you may play, you also haven't lost so much since he's used removal in your 2 drop, clearing the path for your bigger creatures. Then again, if you are running any other kind of graveyard shenanigans, you can get Undertaker again without much trouble.
Add some nice flavour text and art (I really like older Magic style like this - I like new art too, but they just don't print this kind of painting-like pictures much anymore), and you've got a nice 2-drop.

108791: Undertaker.author: blurrymadness
108791: Undertaker.text_parsed:
Similar to Tortured Existence, just a few dredge creatures in your deck effectively gives all of your guys "{B}: Dredge X" (where X is whatever the first card had..)

Stuff like this works amazing with Stinkweed Imp as it give you a 5-card dig for your creature. Shriekmaw is a good example of a powerful combo with this. That said, I'd rather keep it in enchantment form. This guy can attack, be reanimated, etc.. but enchantments, especially 1-mana unimportant ones, are annoying to destroy. There are trade offs, but I too recommend Tortured Existence.

108805: Uncle Istvan.author: Wanderer25
108805: Uncle Istvan.text_parsed:
It was nice seeing this guy in Time Spiral, though I kind of wish that he had shown up in color-shifted form in Planar Chaos. Think about it, he could've been a priest or a monk (Father Istvan, Brother Istvan) in White or Green. Green, I think, would fit more with the flavor of him being a hermit and prevent the shifted version from being a less versatile Cho-Manno, Revolutionary.

Anyway, Uncle Istvan is such a fun, quirky card. His abilities are more what you'd expect from a Beloved Chaplain than a mad, axe- wielding hermit, but that just adds to his appeal..

108805: Uncle Istvan.author: Epicelves
108805: Uncle Istvan.text_parsed: You know, I once had an uncle like Mr. Istvan here. It never really bothered anyone. Until the dreaded first day of pre-school. We were asked to describe a story and it's moral. At the time, it was hard for me. Then I thought of Istvan."My uncle Istvan fought in the Vietnam war, and his plane was shot down over enemy territory. He jumped out before it crashed but could only take a case of beer, a machine gun and a machete. On the way down, he drank the case of beer. Then he landed right in the middle of 100 Vietnamese soldiers. He shot 70 with his machine gun, but then he ran out of bullets! So he pulled out his machete and killed 20 more. Then the blade on his machete broke, so he killed the last ten with his bare hands." The teacher was shocked, but I was happy I got it out. The Moral of the story: Don't #$**#$ with Uncle Istvan.

108806: Uthden Troll.text_parsed:
I'd grab this dude in draft, he 's alright. But more importantly, this card has fantastic flavor. Really, amazing. Wizards should riff on the flavor text in the next core set. Make a card called "Troll Chant." It could be an instant that gives a creature +2/+2 and regenerates it, or something. Make it green, if necessary. The most important thing would be flavor like this:

"Oi oi oi! Me smells'a smelly man!

Oi oi oi! He cutty-pokey can!

gonna nosh-bosh stomp-chomp yum-burp-and-

BetterBetterBetterBetterBetter! Oi oi oi..."

My magical MTG daydream is that WOTC makes "Troll Chant" and uses this flavor text. Also bosh+nosh= best rhyme ever. Kudos to whoever wrote the flavor text of Uthden Troll, its pretty genius. The art ain't bad either. Man, I love this card...

108812: Psionic Blast.author: Cyberium
108812: Psionic Blast.text_parsed: Many people wonder why Psionic Blast is consider more powerful than Char. The answer is simple. Blue, by tradition, isn't the color of aggression. It's on the other side of Red and Green and thus were designed to be more passive and controlling. Psionic Blast is one of the exceptions where planeswalkers could do direct damage to kill a creature or opponent. Combine with other blue control cards, PB is very dangerous, compare to Char is already in a damage-abundant color. Last but not least, there are also way fewer creatures with protection from blue than red.

108816: Giant Oyster.author: Arachnos
108816: Giant Oyster.text_parsed:
Should be called "Giant Clam" instead.

The giant clam can produce huge pearls, and was rumored to close its shell on the hands of divers who would attempt to claim those pearls. Since the shell is huge and heavy, those divers would drown, unable to release themselves from the clam's grasp. Those stories are usually dismissed as legends, as in reality the clam actually closes its shell very, very slowly.

108816: Giant Oyster.author: Zygmus
108816: Giant Oyster.text_parsed:
Loved this card for blue control decks.

Comboed with creatures like Thalakos Dreamsower and Labyrinth Minotaur because they'd allow me to tap and drown the opponents' creatures at will.
The dreamsower could tap a creature, turn it over to the oyster's tender care, go back next turn and tap another one...

A creature heavy deck would be rendered totally helpless and the other player could only watch while their 7/7 fatty just sat there as my shadow creatures and flyers leisurely shaved off the rest of his hit points.
It was so fun to imitate spluttering and bubbling noises and pantomime helpless thrashing each time a creature drowned just to get a furious reaction.

It's annoying as hell, but to his credit, I've now had the unique experience of saying the phrase "Ah f*ck, my guy's got Islandwalk."  Can't help but tip my hat to somebody who kills my creatures by making them [i]too[/i] nimble underwater.

108827: Unstable Mutation.author: jsttu
108827: Unstable Mutation.text_parsed:
@Dr.Jack: You do realize that A) most of the things you listed are primarily blue affects that slightly bleed into green? Those effects are supposed to be weaker due to a different color. B) green dominates when it comes to creatures and will accept no substitutes.Thornling beats morphling any day, ANY flyer, including serendib efreet or azure drake dies to a multitude of 'destroy target creature with flying' spells such as Wing Snare, and Gaea's cradle works much better with a creature deck then tolarian academy ever will. Green is also better in tribal: watch an elf deck fight a merfolk deck. Elf wins hands down.

The great thing about magic is that there are endless possibilities, with five different philosophies with many sub-branches for various deck styles. Blue isn't intrinsically better, as you arrogantly claim, it is just different, and since it has such weird effects sometimes it is hard for Wizards to accurately predict the consequences of some cards, such as tolarian academy or JtMS, thus leading to it's historically broken nature in some areas. If green and blue get into a spell-slinging battle, blue will probably come out on top because that is what is designed around. Bring an epic battle between creature decks and green wins without a sweat. Different philosophies result in different cards and styles.

Incidentally, i prefer giant growth over this because a surprise pump to take out a larger creature is often better than an enchantment that will cause the creature to get chumped or removed.

108827: Unstable Mutation.author: yyukichigai
108827: Unstable Mutation.text_parsed:
The classic combo with this was always to but it on your Serendib Efreet from the same originating set (Arabian Nights). The Efreet suddenly became a 6/7 flyer for 4 mana, and its upkeep cost would take care of itself in 7 turns, if not less from your opponent blocking or killing the gigantic thing that's pummeling them to death.

Another fun one is turn two throwing this on an Ornithopter you cast first turn. 3/5 flyer for {U}? Sure. Why not.

It's a surprisingly aggressive card for Blue, but then again it comes from Magic's first-ever expansion set, long before WotC had the concept of Color Pie pinned down to any degree. Stuck around for a while, too. Great card, great concept. I'd love to see it reprinted, or at least a "colorshifted" variant reprinted in some more fitting color like Black or even Green.

108827: Unstable Mutation.author: DrJack
108827: Unstable Mutation.text_parsed:
Alright, I deleted my original comment because I was basically just ranting about blue being overpowered and green getting the shaft (original, I know).

I was bothered by the fact that many intelligent aspects of green got taken away and moved to blue. Countering activated abilities, repeatably untapping permanents, looking at and rearranging the top cards of your library... I sincerely believe that green should be the master of these powers, and that blue should not.

As far as this Unstable Mutation card goes, you all may disagree, but I strongly feel that blue shouldn't have access to such powerful creature enhancers. Each color has to have weaknesses in some areas. Green is supposed to be the best at boosting creatures; blue is supposed to be the worst. Just as blue has the best flying creatures overall, and green has the worst.

In my opinion, giving blue a card like Unstable Mutation is like black having a Disenchant,
white having a Dark Ritual, red having a Circle of Protection, or green having Swords to Plowshares.

108833: Orcish Librarian.author: sonorhC
108833: Orcish Librarian.text_parsed:
Exiling four at random has almost no net effect on you. In any given game, there are always a bunch of cards in your library that you'll never get to use. The four randomly-chosen cards will be among them, that's all. Yeah, you might end up exiling really good cards, but then again, those really good cards might have been on the bottom of your library, too.

The purpose of this card is to put the others on top of your library in any order. Put the most useful on top, and draw them. Once you've drawn the useful cards, use this guy again, and get more useful cards. This can, in fact, be a way to (almost) guarantee that you don't get any more mountains, after you have all you need.

108833: Orcish Librarian.author: bohplayer
108833: Orcish Librarian.text_parsed:
The random exiling on this card is NOT irrelevant, because you can use the card repeatedly in consecutive turns or even have more than one in play at the same time.

So if you use your first librarian and the 4 cards you get are garbage no matter the order in which you arrange them, just use your second one and there's a good chance that some of those bad cards will be exiled.

Same thing applies if you have only 1 librarian in play, when you decide whether to use him or not the next turn you' ll know the top 3 cards of your deck already, and how much you want them exiled.

If 2 of the 4 cards you got were good, put them on top and don't use his ability for the next 2 turns.

Simply keep putting the good cards on top and the bad cards on bottom, and it's easy to see that the bad cards have a higher chance of getting exiled.

108833: Orcish Librarian.author: Aquillion
108833: Orcish Librarian.text_parsed:
The exiling effect is actually an advantage (as long as you don't overuse it and deck yourself), since you can put the most useful of the next four cards on top, then use him after you draw them and have a decent chance of exiling stuff you don't need (if you don't exile it, put it on the bottom again and keep using it until you do.) Unlike, say, Mirri's Guile or Sensei's Divining Top, which forces you to draw the bad cards eventually, this card combines stacking to get good cards with a way to remove bad or unwanted ones entirely.

That said, I'd still rather use Sensei's Divining Top compared to this. It's cheaper, it's harder to destroy, and its ability to flip with your top card is far more valuable.

Yes, if Faceless Butcher leaves the battlefield before its entry ability resolves, its leaves ability will trigger and resolve (returning nothing), then the entry ability will exile a target creature. You may then replay the Butcher to exile another (maybe pulling the same trick again?)

Vedalken Mastermind with a Butcher becomes 2BBUT: Exile target creature. Certainly a bit pricey compared to the likes of Unmake, but the reusability is probably worth it.

108842: Enduring Renewal.author: liir007
108842: Enduring Renewal.text_parsed:
Card of the Day - January 01, 2008
Time Spiral “timeshifted”. Of all the cards on the Time Spiral timeshifted sheet, Enduring Renewal was the one that worried R&D the most, and it was almost pulled from the set due to power level concerns. The first time around, the card had been abused with 0-cost creatures and Goblin Bombardment in an Extended deck called Fruity Pebbles (incidentally spawning a succession of cereal-related deck names such as Cocoa Pebbles, Trix, Full English Breakfast, and, debatably, Life). The fear was that a similar deck could arise – in Standard, no less – using Wild Cantor and Grapeshot. Ultimately, though, Enduring Renewal was unleashed on the world… only to find that Dragonstorm had beaten it to the breakfast table in the deck that won the 2006 World Championships.

108842: Enduring Renewal.author: Arglypuff
108842: Enduring Renewal.text_parsed: Actually, Ideatog, Opalescence does create enchantment looping. As a creature goes to the graveyard, it maintains it's characteristics from the battlefield until it is in your graveyard. If someone bolted my oblivion ring, for instance, O-ring remains a creature until it is in the graveyard. This means that O-ring is a creature when "it is put into your graveyard," and would thus trigger Enduring Renewal.

108842: Enduring Renewal.author: DrJack
108842: Enduring Renewal.text_parsed: When Enduring Renewal was fairly new, and there was a lot of controversey surrounding it because it made many infinite combos possible, I built a deck based around it to see how easy it was to actually pull it off. A couple of the infinite combo engines involved sacrificing an Ornithopter over and over to a Fallen Angel or Ashnod's Altar. I included Vigilant Martyr to protect the main combo piece (and it could protect my creatures as well). I believe I had reanimators such as Animate Dead or Resurrection to get around Enduring Renewal's drawback. I recall using Ball Lightnings as well, for some obvious synergy with the deck's centerpiece. It turned out to be harder to pull off infinite combos than I thought, the simplest ones involving 3 cards, and I changed my mind about Enduring Renewal being insanely broken. It takes some time to set everything up, and your opponent can make a lot of things go wrong if they're competent. Gameplay with this deck was surprisingly balanced, and when I did succeed, it felt like a real accomplishment.

108842: Enduring Renewal.author: Taos_Jr
108842: Enduring Renewal.text_parsed:
Honestly, my favourite card. It changed Magic for me in 1995 and turned synergy into combo for the first time. Mainly sees play in EDH now but back then it was a lesson to all who played with or against it.

All the relationships have been stated but just do a search on rules text on "Enters" or "Graveyard" for your thing (using the ornithopter, zero CMCs and Su-Chi and altar engine ) add in Citanul Flute. In an equipment deck, Stoneforge Mystic, using this engine, is all your equipment out of your deck into play. Ullamog, the infinite Gyre is a board wipe and Karmic Guide (good already) is insane.

For yucks, if your group allows her, Little Girl instead of a 0 CMC will still give you infinite mana through Phyrexian Altar!

108843: Dragonstorm.author: Equinox523
108843: Dragonstorm.text_parsed: Every so often a card gets reprinted with just enough support in its standard meta to run roughshod on the game. This is one such card. The presence of Seething Song, Rite of Flame, Bogardan Hellkite and Hunted Dragon made this card monstrous, and some decks even ran Gigadrowse to tap the opponent out and make them helpless against the onslaught. There are even som turn 0 kills on record. A shining example of how the right environment can make for some extremely powerful combos, no matter how Timmy-ish they may appear.

108848: Twisted Abomination.author: Laguz
108848: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
One of my favorite cards ever. I just love versatility. It fixes your mana early, and it's a regenerating beatstick late. Stick one swamp in your deck and that's all you need to play him and regenerate him, and he even tutors that swamp up for you. A zombie deck would have plenty of ways to bring him back after cycling him, too.

It was also beautifully drawn by Daren Bader.

108848: Twisted Abomination.author: blurrymadness
108848: Twisted Abomination.text_parsed:
Great card. I find that most of the time, my decks work fine if I get to three mana. 2-mana landcyclers like this really smooth things out when they're this good as they allow you to not only continue moving up the curve, but this guy (the best of them) makes an excellent finisher.

He's tough to kill, eats fairly large creatures, puts a short clock on an opponent, and is color light. Can't ask for much easier of a card to use. Cycle him if you have a card to cast and not enough land; especially at the EOT of an opponent when you're waiting around with kill spells and nothing shows up.

Overpriced? What are you talking about? (4)(B) for a 5/3 that can regenerate for a single mana would be too powerful (and that's not even considering swampcycling). Take a look at what other fatties with cheap regeneration black has. None of those three cards can be swampcycled like the abomination can. This guy is perfectly priced as it is.

A truly great card.
- can mess up even spells with split second
- can change the target on which an aura is played on
- can change the target of equipment (still only on their creatures, but still helps sometimes, when they use their last mana for the equip ability, and it lands then on a guy where it makes no sense)
- works not only on spells but also on abilities

Most often you play it, your opponent will try to kill it beeing scared of the morphed guy. Then you unmorph it, and make them kill one of their own creature, leaving them with a card less in hand, a creature less in play, wasted mana, and you have still some 1/2 dork in play.

108861: Willbender.author: Ladnarud
108861: Willbender.text_parsed:
Yeah, he can't use the ability against a split second card.

You can morph him when a split second is on the stack, but his ability would be negated by the split second because "activated or triggered abilities cannot be played." So essentially, you'd be changing your 2/2 colorless into a 1/2 blue creature for 2 mana, with no triggered ability.

Still an excellent creature. Can be used against things like Banefire, and it has the key difference from things like Swerve because it can be used on spells OR abilities.

4.5/5

108862: Pandemonium.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
108862: Pandemonium.text_parsed: @ VixeyC: Pandemonium says, "...that creature's controller may have it deal damage equal to its power..." Yes, the creature itself is dealing the damage. You can use non-red creatures to deal damage to things with protection from red this way, and deathtouch and lifelink creatures will kill creatures and give you life. Some cards like Niv-Mizzet, Dracogenius will have other effects when dealing damage, those will be triggered. Just check that the ability triggers with non-combat damage. For example, Phage, the Untouchable will still deal damage, but she won't win the game or kill creatures with power more than 4 because she only kills through combat.
108862: Pandemonium.text_posted: @ VixeyC: Pandemonium says, "...that creature's controller may have it deal damage equal to its power..." Yes, the creature itself is dealing the damage. You can use non-red creatures to deal damage to things with protection from red this way, and deathtouch and lifelink creatures will kill creatures and give you life. Some cards like [autocard]Niv-Mizzet, Dracogenius[/autocard] will have other effects when dealing damage, those will be triggered. Just check that the ability triggers with non-combat damage. For example, [autocard]Phage, the Untouchable[/autocard] will still deal damage, but she won't win the game or kill creatures with power more than 4 because she only kills through combat.

108869: Undead Warchief.author: blurrymadness
108869: Undead Warchief.text_parsed:
Think of it as a +2/+1 sorcery to all of your creatures for 4 mana; which makes it a finisher card.
Then think of it as an enchantment that does that.
Then realize it can attack for 3 without other support.

It can quite handily eat a game alive when using zombie tokens or lots of 1-drops and recursion. He turns Gravecrawler into a 1-mana 4/2, and if that doesn't sound brutal; you should see it in game.

His cost reduction is, IMO, worth less than the other warlords, but his buff is worth as much or more. The whole cycle is damn good though.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.author: MisterAction
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed: You're thinking of making her an EDH general, aren't you? Be careful. She's incredibly effective, but she kills fun. When you get her going with a few repeatable untap effects, you can wipe your opponent's creatures in a turn and then leave them grumbling and downtrodden, not even wanting to play creatures because you'll just kill them or throw them back in their faces. She's easy to kill, but cheap enough to cast that she'll come back three or four times in a single game. Your friends will hate her, which is detrimental to the casual environment EDH was intended to create.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.author: Dr.Pingas
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed:
Uhh... I think most people tend to forget, she has a "give the creature back" clause... all you have to do is steal her yourself. Sure, not always easy or effective; but this does set up a few interesting interactions.

A, you steal an indestructible creature. Clearly, she can untap, and "destroy" it. But, you still only control it under the condition that you control Merieke, so if someone bounces her, you get your guy back.

B, the exact opposite, assumes you're stealing an average creature, perhaps with the intention of killing it or some such. So you tap, gain control of it. They use Grab The Reins on her, and you find yourself unable to respond for some raisin; they get her and their dude back. Well, turn passes, you get your Merieke back, tapped, but you decide to untap her to steal something else... and the guy you don't even have control of suddenly dies, because the delayed trigger she creates doesn't seem to be contingent on if you control the creature or not, only that you targeted it, and it resolved.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed: If I tap her to gain control of a creature but flicker her in response to my tap, she then leaves play and comes back before the gain control ability resolves. So what happens? Do you permanently gain control of the creature? Because i think technically you treat the now flickered merieke as a new creature but I still don't know what happens.
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_posted: If I tap her to gain control of a creature but flicker her in response to my tap, she then leaves play and comes back before the gain control ability resolves. So what happens? Do you permanently gain control of the creature? Because i think technically you treat the now flickered merieke as a new creature but I still don't know what happens.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.author: adrian.malacoda
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed:
@justyray: the creature will become destroyed. When you tap her to activate her ability, the ability goes onto the stack. You respond to the ability with something like cloudshift targeting her, cloudshift resolves, she flickers, puts her leaves play trigger onto the stack. The leaves play trigger resolves and destroys the creature. Finally, the tap ability resolves and does nothing. It's like the classic oblivion ring trick.

Once the tap ability has resolved, if you cloudshift the creature you steal (not Merieke), then you get to keep it permanently. If you Ghostly Flicker both of them (as someone else in the comments suggested) then you get to keep the creature and you get to use Merieke again.
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_posted:
@justyray: the creature will become destroyed. When you tap her to activate her ability, the ability goes onto the stack. You respond to the ability with something like [autocard]cloudshift[/autocard] targeting her, cloudshift resolves, she flickers, puts her leaves play trigger onto the stack. The leaves play trigger resolves and destroys the creature. Finally, the tap ability resolves and does nothing. It's like the classic [autocard]oblivion ring[/autocard] trick.

Once the tap ability has resolved, if you cloudshift the creature you steal (not Merieke), then you get to keep it permanently. If you [autocard]Ghostly Flicker[/autocard] both of them (as someone else in the comments suggested) then you get to keep the creature and you get to use Merieke again.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.author: TheMurderousKitten
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed:
Actually, no, I wasn't thinking of making her my EDH general. I have a friend who just built one with her. I haven't played him yet, but I am contemplating ways to steal her from him and use her against him with my Zur the Enchanter deck. I have plenty of thieving spells (Puca's Mischief would do it), and I can use Zur to find that Freed from the Real, Pemmin's Aura or Intruder Alarm to untap her. Nothing like screwing over a friend's control deck by turning his own general against him.

@Myrs:

The whole heavy aspect of Merieke decks is why I suggested stealing her with Puca's Mischief, rather than a more conventional route like Dominate. If you can slip Puca through when your opponent is tapped out, it is no longer counterable. Of course, there is also the fact that I could slip something like Dominate through when my opponent is tapped out as well (it helps that it's an instant). Or there is always the option of using my own counterspells to counter his counters. Just because my spells can be countered doesn't mean the strategy doesn't work. That argument is like the whole "dies to removal" argument. It's technically correct, but so what? The point of my comment was to suggest ways to use control cards to control a control deck, which is always a good time. It won't work every time, but it's still fun to try.

108871: Merieke Ri Berit.author: Aremath
108871: Merieke Ri Berit.text_parsed:
@Stormcrows4Tots: it depends on how you're blinking it out. If you used Cloudshift or Flicker or something like that, they resolve, the creature comes back right after they resolve. Since Merieke's triggered ability is still on the stack, when it resolves the creature dies. If you used Turn to Mist, or Nephalia Smuggler, or something like that, they resolve, the creature gets exiled, the triggered ability resolves, and sees no creature to kill. At the end of the turn, the creature comes back under the control of the player the blink card says it does. (some of them say 'owner's control' and some say 'your control')

@Justyray: This is a similar situation, and it again depends on what cards you use. If your blink card returns to the battlefield immediately (with a 'then' statement), adrian.malacoda is correct. Since her {T} ability resolves after she blinks, the blink effect hasn't done anything. Merieke comes in untapped, but if she dies or becomes untapped, your stolen dude will die. However, if your flicker returns at the end step instead, her ability will resolve with no Merieke on the battlefield to link to the second ability, and you get the creature permanently. Merieke comes back at your end step untapped, ready to steal something new.

I just learned that you can untap her in response to her ability resolving: Here's how that works

-Merieke's {T} ability goes on the stack
-Some instant-speed untap ability in response
-Untap ability resolves, and you can activate her {T} again.

Since you untapped her before you gained control of anything, the triggered ability doesn't do anything yet. Now if she untaps, all of the creatures you control through her will die.

This allows you to permanently gain control of as many guys as you have untap effects. At first I thought untappers just allowed her to kill things for {T}, which is also okay, to be fair.

Rubinia Soulsinger is another similar card, but merieke has a few advantages:

-Soulsigner doesn't kill the creatures when you lose control of them, which means your opponents get their dudes back when she dies or when something bigger you want to grab comes along

-Merieke costs {2} less, which is VERY significant

Since both cards can abuse the stack using untappers, about the same portion of your deck will be devoted to untap combo pieces. You need sac. outlets in Rubinia too, however. Merieke is worse if you can't untap her, but overall, I think Merieke is better overall, but for EDH, it's mostly whether you want green or black since the things you can steal on T3 are mostly irrelevant.

108877: Fire Whip.author: Mode
108877: Fire Whip.text_parsed:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but it bugs me that they changed the card to simplify the wording.

In the original printing, the ability was activated from the aura.
Which is why you can't put this on an opponent's creature, since then you could use it to tap that creature to deal one damage (thereby turning the activation cost into an advantage).

But now it gives the activated to the creature, using the symbol. Which, as we know, means it can't be used by a creature with summoning sickness.
But previously you were able to tap a creature with summoning sickness. (Similar to how Azami can tap herself immediately for her ability).
108877: Fire Whip.text_posted:
Correct me if I'm wrong, but it bugs me that they changed the card to simplify the wording.

In the original printing, the ability was activated from the aura.
Which is why you can't put this on an opponent's creature, since then you could use it to tap that creature to deal one damage (thereby turning the activation cost into an advantage).

But now it gives the activated to the creature, using the [T] symbol. Which, as we know, means it can't be used by a creature with summoning sickness.
[i]But[/i] previously you were able to tap a creature with summoning sickness. (Similar to how [autocard multiverseid="78697"]Azami[/autocard] can tap herself immediately for her ability).

108880: Fiery Temper.author: Cyberium
108880: Fiery Temper.text_parsed:
Many people overlook the obvious difference between this card and Lightning Bolt.

For example, if you play Avatar of Discord or other spells that require discarding, with a hand size of five, you can activate Madness and play Fiery Temper, ended up with two cards and six damage done (Avarar's 2 discard -> 2 Fiery Temper = 3 cards used total).

If you have Lightning Bolt instead and wants to do the same six damage, you ended up with zero cards in hand (Avatar itself + 2 discard + 2 lightning bolts = 5 cards used total).

Lightning Bolt, without a doubt, is stronger because it has no restriction, that does not make these two good comparison with each other. In the example above, Fiery Temper certain wins on card advantage.

4/5

108886: Avoid Fate.author: SkyknightXi
108886: Avoid Fate.text_parsed:
@Killer Nacho: What do you mean "now"? This was printed WAY back in Legends. Thing was, back in those old days, it couldn't shut down just any instant. In fact, only auras and interrupts were fair game. Which meant that the only non-auras it could interdict were the Purelace cycle, Magical Hack, Sleight of Mind, and....I think that's it. (The Heaven's Gate cycle were instants.) Thus, when interrupts were folded into instants, this card got MUCH more useful.

I can't help but wonder if it made an immense impact in TS, considering heirs to it like Vines of Vastwood and Ranger's Guile have been cropping up recently.

108893: Fiery Justice.author: Donovan_Fabian
108893: Fiery Justice.text_parsed:
I don't see how this can have such a bad rating.. it may have a drawback but in a naya deck the 5 life gain is offset by things like thoctars. It has the same power as a bogardan on a 3 mana removal (a mythic rare I might add), and the downside is life gain (which also works with punishing fire just fyi). The other card that was this good that caused life gain is swords to plowshares.. one of the best cards in this game. I suppose if this card has a downside it can really be said to be the extreme color requirement, you basically have to be playing either 5 color or 3 color naya shard to get the use of it.

A fun combo, this + everlasting torment, it deals 5 in wither damage and your opponent doesn't gain any life.

108893: Fiery Justice.text_parsed: This card is good because of its versatility, not because it can combo with other spells for nastiness (that is just a side bonus). Just by itself it can be a 5-for-1 in the best circumstances (usually multiplayer, also early-game EDH), and remember, folks: lifegain sucks. I hate saying that because it's cliche, but most people would very willingly give an opponent 5 life to get card/board advantage like this card can give you. It isn't the most powerful card out there - not by a longshot - but it gets the job done.

108893: Fiery Justice.author: Sasooli
108893: Fiery Justice.text_parsed:
The thing about giving your opponents life is it only matters if you're planning to wear their life total down over time. If your deck plans to win by doing much more than 20 damage in a single turn (either with an infinite combo, or just say an Overrun on top of fifteen Saprolings), you probably don't care about having to do 25 instead.

And of course if you're playing infect - or any alternative win condition like Maze's End or Door to Nothingness - you don't care at all about the lifegain.

@ScissorsLizard: Sure you can. Which is why this card + Isochron Scepter is such a nasty lock on the opponent, once his handsize hits 0.

504. Draw Step
504.1. First, the active player draws a card. This turn-based action doesn’t use the stack.
504.2. Second, any abilities that trigger at the beginning of the draw step and any other abilities that have triggered go on the stack.
504.3. Third, the active player gets priority. Players may cast spells and activate abilities.

108906: Prodigal Sorcerer.author: Ichorix
108906: Prodigal Sorcerer.text_parsed:
@ people wondering why Prodigal Pyromancer is rated lower:

Cards translated to other colors are better or worse depending on how rare their effect is in that color. Cheap damaging effects are easy to come by in red, whereas they're much rarer in blue. However, I do think that this card is rated too highly for its power level, there's definitely a nostalgia bias going on here. Not that I mind though, Tim deserves it for the mark he's left on the game :).

108906: Prodigal Sorcerer.author: Shadows_Vengeance
108906: Prodigal Sorcerer.text_parsed:
@ Sironos:

Prodigal isn't really about worldly pleasure.

Prodigal
adjective
1 spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant
2 having or giving something on a lavish scale
noun
a person who spends money in a recklessly extravagant way.
• (also prodigal son or daughter) a person who leaves home and behaves in such a way, but later makes a repentant return.

108908: Squire.author: Arglypuff
108908: Squire.text_parsed: God, all of y'all need to get a grip. Squire has played an unquestionable role in the game of Magic. There once was a time when Squire really was pretty amazing. And, yes, now it's probably not that effective, but Squire's legacy is undisputable. Why else would Kenji slap on to the table an unmorphed Willbender and exclaim "Squire!" It's because, while he may not be that impressive today, Squire's legacy is what is important.

108908: Squire.author: Skyknight
108908: Squire.text_parsed:
For the record, it was reprinted in order to drive home that no, the past was NOT strictly Mox gems, Mana Drain, Channel, etc. As for its existence in the first place, remember that at the time The Dark came out, the Spike demographic was only just barely beginning to be recognized, compared to the Timmy, Johnny, and Vorthos demographics (not under those names, admittedly...). This was for the Vorthos set.

By the way, it isn't STRICTLY superior to Repentant Blacksmith, at least not if you're playing a red-white deck with things like Giant Strength or Firebreathing (remember, well before Spike was recognized)...

108912: Cockatrice.author: Tiggurix
108912: Cockatrice.text_parsed:
Oh god, people are so ignorant of mythology around here, surprisingly enough. Let me clarify some things:

1. ***atrices are NOT birds or reptiles or any combination between the two. They are fantastical monsters with only superficial resemblances to real animals, and they have the same roots as and are practically indistinguishable from "basilisks" in mythology, basically being two different names for the same monster.

2. The ***atrice or basilisk or whatever one would call it did indeed kill with their gaze, and sometimes possessed toxic breath. It was a popular point in tales about them that the hero killed them by presenting them with a mirror.

3. Gorgons, on the other hand, are much older and basically unrelated monsters that turned people to stone by being so ugly and monstrous that creatures literally would die from seeing them.

Hope that cleared some things up.
108912: Cockatrice.text_posted:

They are fantastical monsters with only superficial resemblances to real animals, and they have the same roots as and are practically indistinguishable from "basilisks" in mythology, basically being two different names for the same monster.

2. The cockatrice or basilisk or whatever one would call it did indeed kill with their gaze, and sometimes possessed toxic breath. It was a popular point in tales about them that the hero killed them by presenting them with a mirror. 

3. Gorgons, on the other hand, are much older and basically unrelated monsters that turned people to stone by being [b]so ugly and monstrous[/b] that creatures literally would die from seeing them.

Hope that cleared some things up.

108912: Cockatrice.author: Mode
108912: Cockatrice.text_parsed:
They changed Lycanthropes (Lesser Werewolf, Greater Werewolf) into Human Wolf as well, so why not this specimen?
According to Mythology, a Cóckatrice is a chimera of a two-legged dragon with a rooster's head, so that would make it Dragon Bird. Which is a pretty rad type combination.

Then again, they usually keep quirky types for a reason. (At least since the Grand Creature Type Update).
For example, Kavu could be Lizard Beasts, Homarids could be Crabs, and Cephalids could Octopuses instead.

Although, Kavu aside, seeing how all other humanoid, animal-based species don't get a seperate type either, i actually think they shouldn't have a seperate type: There's literally an example for every major animal species: We have Aven (Birds), Nantuko (Insects), Leonin (Cats), Nezumi (Rats) and most notably Orochi (Snakes), which look less similar to actual Snakes than Homarids or Cephalids do to their respective species.

Edit:
Alright, i could probably have guessed it, but it looks like Wizard kept that type because they still had plans with it:
It seems there will be Cóckatrices (that's the plural term, right?) in M14, like Deathgaze Cóckatrice*.
Well, maybe it's just this one. But if there are more, expect them all to have Flying and Deathtouch.

Still, i don't get why they wouldn't just make them Dragon Birds.
I mean, come on - that's one of the coolest type combinations since Simic's Crocodile Frog.

*Unfortunately, the word filter won't allow me to link to this card by name, and since i don't know the multiverse ID yet, i'll just link the first part of its name (which will currently result in the only card that starts with those letters).

108912: Cockatrice.author: SkyknightXi
108912: Cockatrice.text_parsed:
The way the bestiaries had it, the basilisk/***atrice were the result of a rooster's egg (yes, you read that correctly) being incubated non-stop by a toad. The name "***atrice" may in some way be related to the egg element; originally, it was just "basilisk". That one means "little king", because it was held to be the king of serpents, looking like a small viper with a white crest. So I'd guess that when the rooster's egg bit came up, that's when the basilisk/***atrice began to sport feathers.

Note, by the way, that the bestiaries didn't think the gaze or breath of the basilisk/***atrice killed by petrification. Rather, it was by inducing a severe case of poisoning. How bad? The basilisk's breath was supposed to kill EVERYTHING in a radius of a few miles except the rue plant (the Sahara Desert? Their doing.), and could even make rocks EXPLODE. That latter may have to do with the idea that serpent venom was incendiary in some way, simply because snakebite victims felt a burning sensation at the wound ("seraphim" was, in fact, normally applied to ordinary vipers in the Hebrew original of the Old Testament, precisely because of that sensation). Thus, you either got killed outright, or suffered spontaneous combustion. Stabbing a basilisk was a perilous because the venom was in their blood, too, and would wick right up the spear and kill you at the moment of contact. Best thing to do was to drop a weasel, supposedly horribly filthy as a matter of course, into a basilisk's den, and wait for them to kill each other with their respective odors.

So, if you wanted to be picky, this COULD be a Snake Bird. But then, the chimerae in Theros aren't Lion Goats or the like (sorry Goatnapper).

Thus, you either got killed outright, or suffered spontaneous combustion. Stabbing a basilisk was a perilous because the venom was in their blood, too, and would wick right up the spear and kill you at the moment of contact. 108914: Conspiracy.author: crenel
108914: Conspiracy.text_parsed:
Conspiracy + Sporoloth Ancient + Sporesower Thallid and you have a growing army of fungus that creates more of itself, constantly. Use with Doubling Season for added effect. Just make sure to declare that all of your creatures are to become Fungi; essentially, your Saprolings will create more Saprolings.

Conspiracy + Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero + literally any creature with trample, haste, and a nice hefty attack power. You can pull out Lin Sivvi, Defiant Hero (or if Conspiracy is in play anything) with Amrou Scouts, Blightspeakers, Defiant Falcons, Defiant Vanguards, Ramosian Captains, Ramosian Lieutenants, Ramosian Sergents, or Ramosian Sky Marshals. Really the deck sets itself up for some fantastic plays and runs just fine as white/black. Best of all is that almost all of it plays within block.

108914: Conspiracy.author: uoldgoat
108914: Conspiracy.text_parsed:
Bala Ged Thief + Nath of the Gilt-Leaf + Conspiracy = All opponents discard their hand during your upkeep and any time you play a creature, and you get a 1/1 Elf Ally for each card discarded.

Since you're already using B + G, may as well throw in Turntimber Ranger. As mentioned, that + conspiracy = infinite (or arbitrarily large) number of wolf allies.

Throw in the 2 uncommon B & G allies from ZEN, and now you're draining life & killing fliers along with it.

This sure sounds like a fun casual multiplayer deck. Going to throw in some Essence Wardens & Megrims to act as lures for spot removal as everybody I play has (justifiably) mad hate for those cards.

Other fun things to use with Conspiracy:
Haakon, Stromgald Scourge
Any sliver
Any lord with a potent ability.

crenel's combos sound right up my ally-- err I mean alley. :)

108914: Conspiracy.author: achilleselbow
108914: Conspiracy.text_parsed:
Pretty sure Turntimber Ranger wouldn't work. Conspiracy affects creature CARDS you own, creature SPELLS you control, and creatures already in play. A wolf token coming into play is none of those things. Unlike a creature card or spell, a token doesn't exist in any game zone except the battlefield and in any form except as a permanent - all that exists until then is the Ranger's triggered effect on the stack, which Conspiracy does not affect. Once the token hits the battlefield it will indeed become an ally, but then it's already be too late to trigger comes-into-play ally effects.
Also would not work with Wirewood Hivemaster because it specifies that it only triggers on NONTOKEN elves coming into play.
Basically, token generators are not the way to go if you're trying to combo this card. Plenty of other uses though.
Sorry to burst everyone's bubble.

Continuous effects that modify the properties of a permanent, start modifying it as soon as the spell (a.k.a. soon-to-be-permanent-spell) resolves and is about to hit the battlefield, thus making the wolves come into play as wayward adventurers instead of wood-dwelling beasts.

Force of Savagery is a card that would be impossible to use if it didn't work this way

108914: Conspiracy.author: d-101
108914: Conspiracy.text_parsed:
Ok, I just wanna point this out before m14 comes out;
Conspiracy + Xathrid Necromancer will allow you to create zombie tokens when your zombie tokens die, if you declare "human" as the type when Conspiracy comes into play. As long as the Necromancer is protected, and Conspiracy remains in play, you can have an infinite amount of tokens die. This can be bonkers in casual with cards like Bloodthrone Vampire, and with Blasting Station you have an infinite damage combo:
Play Necromancer.
Play Conspiracy, declare humans, and have ANY other creature on the field.
Play Blasting Station, tap it, sacrifice the other creature to deal one damage to your opponent. Since it's a human, a zombie token enters the battlefield. Blasting Station untaps since a creature came into play; sacrifice the zombie token to Blasting Station. Since it's a human, another zombie token will come into play tapped. Blasting Station untaps, and you can sacrifice the new human-zombie token. Repeat until opponent(s) are dead.
(also works with Blood Artist and Bloodthrone Vampire)
Ok, I think I just found my favorite stupid deck ever.
108914: Conspiracy.text_posted:

108914: Conspiracy.author: RedJaron
108914: Conspiracy.text_parsed:
@Kelptic You can use Scion's ability as many times per turn as you want, you just have to use them all at the same time in response to each other. They all go on the stack and will resolve so you can send as many cards to the grave as you want, however Scion will end up being a copy of the first creature actually targeted. Whether there's a state check in between each ability resolving, and checking who is actually attacking, I don't know, but I don't think so.

@ VampireBlood Yes, Scion will be a copy until end of turn. The copy effect isn't dependent on the card staying in the graveyard.

108916: Tribal Flames.author: Lifegainwithbite
108916: Tribal Flames.text_parsed:
A lot of people are really undervaluing this card. Even in the early game, it will often deal at least 2-3 damage which is decent because it has the potential to deal 5 damage in the late game. 5 damage for 2 is ridiculous - look at Flame javelin which is 4 damage for three or Lava axe which is 5 damage for 5 and can only target creatures.

In the right sort of deck, this is just card advantage and it can hit it's full potential as early as turn 3. Bolt may be better in most situations but in a deck built around it, I'd much rather have this just for how much it does.

This is the Tarmogoyf of burn spells - it's decent in the early game and fantastic when you have enough juice for it which can be as early as turn 3.

You build a deck around this card because it's simply that good. I main a 5-color domain deck in modern and between this, Might of Alara, and Geist of Saint Traft you will be begging for me to topdeck a lighting bolt instead of this card. Combined with Snapcaster Mage this card can single handedly win the game, especially in Modern where people shock and fetch themselves down to lower life.

108917: Desolation Giant.author: SAUS3
108917: Desolation Giant.text_parsed:
Reading the comments for this card, this thing is totally underrated. Board wiping and leaving a creature behind is very powerful. In emergencies, he can at least be a 3/3 blocker for you.

Overall, I'd agree that it's usually worse than martial coup, but not always. Being 1 less mana is quite significant.

Ignore the fact that if you don't pay the kicker, he blows up your own board. You choose to pay the kicker if you want, so look at him as more of a 6 mana creatures that kills all other creatures when he comes into play.

Sure, he's a 3/3, but that's one hell of an ETB effect. The kicker just makes him less abusable - which is probably a good thing.

I am using him in my Tajic duel commander deck which uses Tajics indestructibility by constantly blowing up the board with wrath of god effects, and using creatures that dodge them (manlands, gideon, this guy) to activate battalion against empty boards. This guy is quite good there.

108919: Darkness.author: DarthParallax
108919: Darkness.text_parsed:
I think that some effects ought to be in all 5 colors, and Fog is one of them. However, the card Fog doesn't perfectly translate to all 5 colors. Legends was the third Magic setting ever, after Alpha and Arabian Nights, right? I think Darkness is 'bad' in that it too much pigeonholes the potential of this 'cycle' as having to be exact copycats of Fog.

And in Time Spiral, they brought it back only as a Timeshifted card, but it doesn't even totally fit to me as a Planar Chaos-like idea.

The other colors of Fog should not be exact mechanical copycats, but I do think they need cards that they would use as 'their Fog'.

Blue should be a 2-mana enchantment with an activated ability, or a 3-mana enchantment that 'just works', that gives something like Fog to one creature. NOT Shroud, Shroud is stupid, but Fog/Holy Day isn't stupid, it's cool but still reasonable. :) Call it something like Mirror Shield or Magic Water Shield or...you get the idea. We all know what a Blue Fog would kind of look like. Not Fog Bank (a good creature, but just not the same), but the actual spell-that-prevents-damage as opposed to a creature with the Magic built in.

Red "Fog" would be awesome. "Fog of Fire": "Combat damage from creatures is redirected to their controllers this turn."

This would be an awesome blowout card or save-you card. It needs more balancing than just that obviously- this is just a very crude concept, but you start by costing it at 3 or even 4 mana ({2}{R}{R}). I'm not saying "Red Fog" would be easy to make, but I think it can, and should. Something to actually be as cool in constructed as Wall of Fire is in....nowhere?

108920: Leviathan.author: JaxsonBateman
108920: Leviathan.text_parsed:
The problem with this guy is that he doesn't have any protection from removal. 9 mana to play him, effectively taking up a whole turn's worth of mana. 2 land sac to untap him. 2 more if you want to attack with him. At that point, the opponent can pay as little as one for something like Path to Exile or Swords to Plowshares to get rid of it (although you prob would hope for something less painful than Swords with a 10/10 ^^).

He could be a workable attacker if you're able to give him vig, or he'd make a somewhat decent defender (the only major benefit over a much cheaper wall being that he would kill a lot of attackers), but as a traditional attacker the drawbacks are just way too much.
